heading.title: PART 74 TRANSFERS OF PROCEEDINGS; CROSS-VESTING LAWS [rr 4–9]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 74 TRANSFERS OF PROCEEDINGS; CROSS-VESTING LAWS [rr 4–9]

p.text: [Div 3 insrt Amendment 209: Gaz 102 of 17 June 1988 p 3187]

In this Division, unless the context or subject matter otherwise indicates or requires, subject Act means the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987 or the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987 of the Commonwealth.
Expressions used in this Division shall have, unless the contrary intention appears, in relation to proceedings under a subject Act, the same meaning as in that subject Act.
In this Division a reference to an application to the Court under a subject Act includes a reference to a request under section 6(6) of that subject Act.
Also see UCP Rules 44.2 .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 74.4.1] Cross-vesting laws and Wakim's case

p.text: The High Court's decision in Re Wakim: Ex parte McNally (1998) CLR 511; (1999) 163 ALR 270; 31 ACSR 99Â held that the cross-vesting laws were invalid in so far as they purported to confer state jurisdiction on federal courts. As a result of that decision the New South Wales Parliament enacted the Federal Courts (State Jurisdiction) Act 1999. That legislation provided a mechanism for preserving the rights and liabilities of parties to previous federal court decisions by declaring that they could be enforced as if they were rights arising under Supreme Court judgments. The legislation also provided a mechanism for the transfer of pending proceedings to the Supreme Court and for determining the parties' rights and liabilities (particularly having regard to any relevant limitation law) on the deemed basis that the proceedings had originally been commenced in the Supreme Court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 74 r 5] r 5 Mode of application

p.text: Also see UCP Rules 44.3 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 74 r 6] r 6 Addition above title

p.text: Where a party to any proceeding in the Court intends to contend that:
the Court should exercise jurisdiction pursuant to any provision of a subject Act or any law of the Commonwealth or a State relating to cross-vesting of jurisdiction; or
that the Court should transfer the proceeding to another Court pursuant to any such provision or law,
the party shall add “Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Acts 1987” to the first document filed by that party.
[r 6 subst Amendment 211: Gaz 147 of 23 September 1988 p 4995 ; am Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [84], effective 15 August 2005]

The rules of court that prescribe procedures to be followed under cross-vesting legislation are uniform across Australia. It is therefore important that all rules be complied with: Jackson v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1988) 96 FLR 145Â (plaintiff ordered to comply with equivalent of r 6 before order for transfer to another court made).

If an application for the transfer of proceedings pending in the Court is made by the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth or a State or Territory under a subject Act, the Attorney-General shall not, by reason of the application, become a party to those proceedings.
Also see UCP Rules 44.4 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 74 r 8] r 8 Application relating to transfer

p.text: Where a party to any proceeding in the Court intends to contend that:
the Court should exercise jurisdiction pursuant to any provision of a subject Act or any law of the Commonwealth or a State relating to cross-vesting of jurisdiction; or
that the Court should transfer the proceeding to another Court pursuant to any such provision or law,

the party shall, on or as soon as practicable after commencement of the proceedings, apply to the Court for a determination of the question whether or not the proceeding should be transferred to another Court.
Also see UCP Rules 44.5 .

The court may transfer part of the proceedings constituted by separate causes of action: Jackson v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1988) 96 FLR 145Â (claim for damages under Trade Practices Act 1974 (Cth) s 52 transferred, but defamation claim not transferred). However, there is no power to transfer only a part of a cause of action: Blake v Norris (1990) 20 NSWLR 300Â (question of liability for negligence could not be transferred, separately from the question of damages).

Under s 5 of the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-Vesting) Act 1987, the court has a wide power to transfer proceedings whenever it is satisfied that the “interests of justice” render another court a “more appropriate” forum. These statutory criteria are inherently general and distinguish the power conferred by the cross-vesting legislation from the court's power to stay proceedings in cases of forum non conveniens: see James Hardie & Co Pty Ltd v Barry (2000) 50 NSWLR 357; [2000] NSWCA 353; BC200007474Â ; BHP Billiton Ltd v Schultz (2004) 211 ALR 523; 79 ALJR 348; [2004] HCA 61; BC200408297Â and CPA [s 67.50] . Under the cross-vesting legislation the discretion to transfer proceedings involves an essentially administrative decision made in the interests of justice: Bankinvest AG v Seabrook (1988) 14Â NSWLR 711; 90 ALR 407 per Street CJ.

There are several statements to the effect that there is no onus on the party seeking transfer of proceedings under the cross-vesting legislation: Bankinvest, supra, per Street CJ and Rogers AJA; see also Australian Consolidated Investments Ltd v Westpac Banking Corp (1991) 5 ACSR 233Â (per Rolfe J); Midland Montague Australia Ltd v O'Connor (1991) 109 FLR 285; Chapman v Jansen (1990) 100 FLR 66 at 81Â ; Linter Group (in liq) v Price Waterhouse (1992) 9 ACSR 346Â ; Arrowcrest Group Pty Ltd v Advertiser News Weekend Publishing Co Pty Ltd (1993) 113 FLR 57 at 61Â . However, it is probably more accurate to say that, whilst questions of onus are unlikely to be decisive in any particular case, the moving party at least bears a persuasive onus of showing that transfer of the proceedings is appropriate in all the circumstances: James Hardie & Co Pty Ltd v Barry (2000) 50 NSWLR 357; [2000] NSWCA 353; BC200007474Â .

heading.title: No presumption in favour of the existing forum

p.text: There is no presumption that the court whose jurisdiction has been invoked should exercise that jurisdiction: see also Midland Montague Australia Ltd v O'Connor (1991) 109 FLR 285 at 293; Chapman v Jansen (1990) 100 FLR 66 at 81Â ; Harrison v Trewhella (1994) 122 FLR 90 at 98; 13 WAR 394; BC9401940Â ; Linter Group (in liq) v Price Waterhouse (1992) 9 ACSR 346Â ; Nilsen Electric (WA) Pty Ltd v Jovista Pty Ltd ACN 009171420 (t/as SDR Construction) (VSC, Byrne J, 8 March 1995, unreported, BC9503233); Junemill Ltd (in liq) v FAI General Insurance Co Ltd (VSC, HayneÂ J, NoÂ 2172/93, 23 February1994, unreported, BC9405107).

The width of the statutory criteria for transfer under the cross-vesting legislation is similar to the liberal forum non conveniens test applied in England, which with its emphasis on considerations of fairness and convenience in choosing the more appropriate forum for the conduct of the proceedings: see Spiliada Maritime Corp v Cansulex Ltd [1987] AC 460; [1986] 3 All ER 843Â ; broadly corresponds to the criteria in the cross-vesting legislation. See (1988) 62 ALJ 1016. Relevant matters include:
the place where parties reside or carry on business;
the location of the subject matter of the dispute;
the importance of local knowledge to the resolution of the issues;

the law governing the relevant transaction (especially if the matter involves the construction of state legislation): Australian Consolidated Investments Ltd v Westpac Banking Corp (1991) 5 ACSR 233Â ; National Dairies (WA) Ltd v Wesfarmers Ltd (FCA, Tamberlin J, 22 July 1996, unreported, BC9603177);
the procedures to be adopted (including the facility of reference to a referee: Trade Practices Commission v Collings Construction Co Pty Ltd (1994) 53 FCR 137; 130 ALR 115Â ; and
the likely hearing date: Bourke v State Bank of New South Wales (1988) 22 FCR 378 at 394; 85 ALR 61Â ;
whether it is sought to transfer the proceedings to a court with special jurisdiction, for example, the Family Court: Lambert v Dean (1989) Fam LR 285; 97 FLR 352.

An exclusive jurisdiction clause nominating the courts of a particular state as the forum for the resolution of disputes between the parties is a significant, if not determinative, factor on a cross-vesting application: West's Process Engineering Pty Ltd (admin apptd) v Westralian Sands Ltd (NSWSC, Rolfe J, No 50147/97, 6 August 1997, unreported, BC9703418); Air Attention WA v Seeley International Pty Ltd (WASC, WalshÂ J, NoÂ 1479/96, 3Â September 1996, unreported, BC9604200); Power and Water Authority v McMahon Contractors Pty Ltd (NTSC, Angel J, 21 September 1995, unreported) cf Nilsen Electric (WA) Pty Ltd v Jovista Pty Ltd (VSC, Byrne J, 8 March 1995, unreported, BC9503233).

Where proceedings in a Supreme Court involve essentially a contract dispute, it is likely that the interests of justice will require the proceedings remain in the state court, unless there is some significant federal element in the dispute or some other special consideration, such as limitation on the remedies available in the state court. The mere fact that the proceedings involve a claim under the Trade Practices Act 1974 (Cth) does not indicate the presence of a significant federal element: Glowtide Pty Ltd v Oceanic Life Ltd (1996) 19 ACSR 471Â .

The cross-vesting legislation was obviously not intended to facilitate “forum shopping” where parties seek to derive advantages from the procedural or substantive law of a particular forum: Jackson v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1988) 96 FLR 145Â ; Staples v McCall (1989) 98 FLR 152 at 157Â ; Chapman v Jansen (1990) 100 FLR 66 at 80Â . However, this general proposition has led to some differences of approach where a potential limitation defence is available in one or other forum. The existence of such a potential defence in the state to which it is sought to be transferred was held to be an irrelevant consideration in Taylor v Trustees of the Christian Brothers (1994) Aust Torts Reports Â¶81-288, see also Jenkins v Australian Shipping Commission (NSWSC, Loveday J, 13 September 1991, unreported). On the other hand, it was regarded as a relevant consideration against transfer in Newton v Queensdown Pty Ltd (Sully J, 7 May 1993, unreported); Magian v Mount Isa Mines Ltd (QSC, Studdert J, 31 August 1993, unreported) and DJ v Trustees of the Christian Brothers (15 December 1994, unreported) per Levine J; National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Nabalco Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Rogers CJ, 1 August 1989, unreported, BC8901895). This latter group of cases may require qualification in light of Brisbane South Regional Health Authority v Taylor (1996) 186 CLR 541; 139 ALR 1Â .

Where proceedings under the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) are commenced in a state and second proceedings are commenced in another state, the second court will usually transfer them to the first court under s 44 of the Corporations (New South Wales) Act 1990 (NSW), but may adjourn the application to enable the first court to consider special reasons for ordering transfer to the second court: Re Tungsten Investments Pty Ltd (1991) 9 ACLC 1162Â . In circumstances where there are proceedings on foot in two courts and each court declines to transfer the proceedings before it to the other court and also refuses an application to have the proceedings before it stayed, one court may grant an injunction restraining the continuance of the other proceedings: Pegasus Leasing Ltd v Cadoroll Pty Ltd (1996) 59 FCR 152Â .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 74 r 9] r 9 Application of other laws or rules

leg:heading.title: Application of other laws or rules5

p.text: Where a party wishes to contend that the Court should, under section 11(1)(b) or (c) of a subject Act, apply the written law of another State or Territory or the rules of evidence or procedure other than those applied in the State, the party shall, as soon as practicable:
file notice of the contention, specifying the law or rules and stating the grounds relied upon in support of the contention;
forthwith after filing the notice, serve it on each other party;
The Court may, on the application of a party to a proceeding or of its own motion, give directions in relation to the application of a law or rule under section 11(1)(b) or (c) of a subject Act.
Also see UCP Rules 44.6 .
